segments.text: This is Brent Weldon interviewing Bill Farmer on the subject of Vietnam.
Do you acknowledge that you're in using this for a donation to the oral history collection for Texas A&M University?
Yes.
Could you first start when and where you were born?
I was born here in Waco, Texas in 1949, June.
Did you grow up here?
Grew up in Waco.
Okay.
Where did you go to school, high school?
Graduated from University High School here in Waco.
Okay.
Did you go to college anywhere?
Yes.
I went to MCC, graduated from Baylor University, got my master's degree from North Texas State University.
Okay.
When did you graduate?
When did you get those?
Graduated from Baylor in 1974 and received my master's in 19...
81, I believe, if I remember correctly.
And what time did you serve in Vietnam?
From September of 1968 to September of 1969.
And what branch and outfit was that?
Well, I was with the United States Army.
My immediate assignment was with 378th Maintenance Company and was TDY with 11th Armored Cavalry Regiment.
Why did you volunteer instead of waiting to be drafted or trying to get a deferment?
Well, I was 18 years old.
College wasn't where I wanted to be at that particular time.
It wasn't doing too well.
And I just felt the need to go.
My parents had been, my dad had been, my uncles had been in Korea all the way back to World War I, my grandfathers, my cousins.
I had cousins in Vietnam.
I just felt like it was where I needed to do instead of wasting my time doing nothing.
Okay.
Did you feel that the United States was right in responding by sending troops for combat?
Yes, I do.
I think we were doing the right thing.
Why did you feel like that?
Well, at that time...
You know, communism was a big thing.
We still had the Cold War was going on, the threat of nuclear war, the spread of communism, the things that you hear about all the time.
Okay.
I really felt like it was the right thing to do.
We needed to stop it in Southeast Asia.
Okay.
Did you feel that when you went in, did you feel that the United States would win?
Most definitely.
Most definitely.
Never thought we would lose the war.
You just felt that we would never lose?
Is that why?
Okay.
Okay.
How did you feel in response?
I still debate the fact that we lost the war.
We didn't lose the war.
Congress helped us maybe, but we didn't lose the war.
How did you feel in response to friends and acquaintances who could have gone and didn't go?
Well, I never really knew anyone who tried to avoid the war.
Some who went to school were there that I knew of were there because they wanted to get education.
It was not to dodge the war, so it's hard to answer that.
My immediate friends...
They either went or they were in school for a real reason, or they couldn't go for medical reasons.
I really had no one to try to dodge the war that I know of.
Oh, that's interesting.
How did you feel about the strategic bombing?
Did you feel it was effective?
Well, I feel like it was doing what it was supposed to do.
I remember there were a lot of times where we didn't have any contact with the enemy, and I thought it was due to the bombing.
Nixon halted the bombing, I guess, October, November 1968, somewhere there.
It's been such a long time.
Immediately after that, it wasn't long and the enemy activity picked up all through the country, as far as I know.
So, did you feel that you were adequately trained when you got there for what you had to do?
Well, not really.
Mostly you learned from others on the job training.
I felt it was very difficult
to train for what we were doing and for the kind of war we were fighting, because it was a whole different kind of war.
It wasn't like anything that we had done before.

Even my dad had talked about being in the Philippines in World War II, and after we'd talked a little bit, and he said even, it didn't sound like it was even the same thing then, and his was a jungle-type warfare in World War II.
So I don't know as we
were trained as well as we needed to be.
I don't know if we had enough knowledge to train the way we needed to.
Until the latter part of the war, and by the time we got to that point, it was basically too late.
So I think most of it was on-the-job training.
Okay.
Did you... How did the anti-war activism in the States, did that make you feel...
How did that make you feel while you were in the service?
Did it have any kind of impact in Vietnam?
Well, it made a lot angry, particularly those that were probably young like I was.
It bothered us a little bit to read the newspapers, to get a news clip or something of all this stuff that was going on.
It was bothersome.
And many of the older, what few there were, the older military people, of course they were
in the military for life so it really bothered them that this was going on.
Was there any kind of anti-war around where you were at?
Not particularly.

We had the typical things you see in the movies, guys wearing peace signs and you know a lot of guys would talk about wish they were somewhere else and didn't know why they were there and things like that but when push came to shove
everyone that I've ever been in contact with did their job and was proud to serve.
They may not have liked being there, but they did what they felt like they had to do.
How did you feel about Nixon's Vietnamization policy before, during, and then after the war?
Well, it was a good goal, but it wasn't too realistic from what little bit.
You know, I don't know that much about that kind of thing.

But I do know that most of the time, even though the Vietnamese really tried very hard, most of them had been fighting for so many years, it was hard for them to, I don't know if motivated is a good word or not, to continue the fight.
Many of their troops were very good fighters, and many of their troops also, I don't know, it wasn't that they were bad fighters, it's just that they didn't,
do what they needed to do at times.
It was scary for them.
It was just such a long, drawn out thing.
And like I said, we were there 10, 11, 12 years maybe, a little bit before that with advisors, but those guys had been fighting for 25 and 30 years.
So it was hard for them just to keep on keeping on.
How did you feel about the TV and newspaper journalists that were over there?
Well, we didn't really have that much contact with them.
They were around here and there, but really they weren't very, I don't know if effective is a good word.
They didn't bother us.
We did our job, and they weren't around very long.
They would be there, and then they were gone doing something else.
So really couldn't say a whole lot about it.
Did they ever interview anybody?
No.
They were taking pictures more than anything else.
Was that bothersome that they took a lot of pictures or anything?
No, not necessarily, because most of the pictures they took were at times where they weren't in the way or where they weren't in real danger.
I'm sure there were some media people who were in situations where it was quite dangerous, but I was never around those that were in that situation.
So my next question was if you felt that the journalists took away from morale at all.
Would that affect you at all?
Well, we never had any.
I never knew of any that said or did anything to knock what we were doing.
They were all supportive as far as I know.
I had asked you this before, but do you feel that war should have been declared on the records?
Well, only if they would allow the war to actually be fought.
I don't feel like, and I know many others, don't feel like we were allowed to fight the war.
I mean, why declare a war if you're not allowed to fight it?
You know, like it ought to be fought, put an end to it.
We're held back.
So I don't see the need.
I didn't see the need, and still don't, why there would have been a declaration of war.
Maybe it would have made Congress feel good, but...
When you're prevented from doing your job in some ways, well, what's the use?
For those in the field, it really didn't make a difference.
Right.
If it had been your decision, would you have done something different than what was done?
Like, they sent troops, but they didn't declare war.
Would you have done something different than that if you had had a say?
Well, I don't know enough about what all we had.
But I think that we, given the opportunity, maybe we should have declared war.
And then we could have went on in.
And we needed to go ahead and invade North Vietnam, put an end to it.
So we were fighting a defensive war rather than an aggressive war.
And we should have went on and did what we needed to do.
If it meant crossing into North Vietnam, we needed to do that, or into Cambodia, or Laos, or whatever.
I know we were in those areas when we weren't supposed to be, but that should have never happened.
We should have been there if we needed to be there and go on.
Now that's a low soldier's idea.
The general advice had to look a little different, but we wanted to win.
What do you think the difference would have made if war had been declared?
Well, if we had have declared war, we might have went ahead and did some things that we didn't do.
We might have really...
went on the aggressive rather than trying to be fighting defensively.
I don't see how you can win a war defensively.
What do you think their objectives were for sending troops over?
Well, I think the whole thing was just to buy time so that the Vietnamization program would work and they could fight their own war, but that was never going to happen.
It didn't take long to really realize that, and then we got ourselves in so deep, it seems to me like
we wouldn't quit.
We wouldn't shut it down.
We wouldn't stop.
There was no easy way out.
No one wanted to ever lose the war, but yet we didn't do the things we needed to do to actually win the war.
There was talk about use of atomic bombs.
Did you ever hear anything about this?
No.
How do you feel now about the possibility of what they might have used atomic bombs?
Well, I don't know if that would have been such a good idea.
There was enough civilians being hurt and killed and maimed and loss of life and land and all of that.
I don't know if that would have been really good or not.
That's a hard one to call.
Okay.
Did you ever see any kind of use of drugs that are now illegal in the United States among the troops?
There was drug use.
I was around drug use many times.
Some used drugs.
Marijuana primarily was the drug most used.
Alcohol was used quite a bit.
But I must say that none of these things were ever done around me or anyone that I know of at a time when we were involved in an operation of any kind.
Those things always happened.
pursued that kind of activity, did that when we were back at a base camp or a place of safety or they were off duty.
I know it doesn't make it right, but they did those kinds of things.
I was around it.
It was common practice.
But again, I have to emphasize, no one that I know of ever did that at a time when it was life or death or on a mission or operation that I know of.
Okay, I understand.
Did you see a lot of strong apathy about the war while you were in it?
Well, not too much, really.
When I came home in 1969, the morale was still pretty strong.

I don't think that a lot of the apathy, I don't really think that a lot of the drug use really, really got bad until probably toward the end of the war, 71, 72, 70, in those times when it was evident that we weren't going to do anything to win the war.
We were just killing time, trying to figure a way to come home.
I understand.
How did you feel about the use of drugs around?
Well, I didn't like it.
I don't use drugs, and I knew a lot of good guys that did drugs, but they were still, I thought, were good guys.

They just had a vice that I didn't think was proper, but again, they were smart enough or old enough or whatever you want to call it to do it where it did not affect the lives of those around them as far as I know.
Was it ever bad enough where you were at that there were combat refusals or fragging?
No.
No?
Again, I think a lot of that that you see in the movies or read about, I think a lot of that came late in the war.
Later in the war.
Okay.
Did you ever have any opinion about that after you were here, hearing about the combat refusals and the fragging that was going on?
Well...
I can't see that being done.
Okay, I understand.
I just don't see it happening.
I know that it did in situations, but it would be hard to make a judgment without actually knowing that situation.

Because I know there were many times where you were given orders or told to do things, and maybe by someone who had only been there a short time and had not learned the ropes, and you'd want to say, hey, this is not how we need to do it.
For the most part, those people who were in those positions of leadership listened to those who had been there before.
I think maybe as the war progressed toward the end, that didn't happen like that.
They didn't listen to those who had been there.

So it wasn't unusual early, I don't think, for, say, a new lieutenant right out of OCS to listen to an old sergeant who'd been there six, seven, eight, nine, maybe in their second tour, said, hey, we need to do this a little differently.
And they would listen.
You know, they were smart enough to listen.
Maybe some of these other things occurred later.
Okay, but not while you were around?
No.
Okay.

What did you think about, while we're talking about the officers, what did you think about the careerism we talked about in our class about how some of the officers would go in long enough to get a promotion and then they'd be transferred six months later?
What did you think about that?
Was there a lot of that where you were at?
Really, no.
I never seen too many who came in just for a while to get a little experience and ship them out.
Most that came stayed.
Stayed through their tour just like anybody else.
I'm really not familiar with career movements or anything like that, just to get them a stripe or get them a bar or anything like that.
I'm just not familiar with that.
Did you feel that the tour of duty was 365 days, is that right?
Do you feel that that was too short or should it have been longer?
Well, I was glad it was short.
I don't know of anyone that wasn't glad it was short.
But really, it took a while for the on-the-job training to take place.
So I don't know how much that affected our capabilities or whatever.
But after two or three months, we probably maybe should have stayed a little bit longer.
Because it seems like there was always somebody new.
There was always someone around that was being trained or learning the ropes.
So you never...
Seemed like you had a unit that was working together for a full year.
You were always worrying about somebody new and them learning ropes and trying to take care of each other.
So maybe it was too short.
I really don't know.
What kind of nicknames did y'all have?
Did y'all ever have any kind of pet names?
No, not particularly.
We didn't.
That's pretty much Hollywood stuff.
I think so.
We didn't.
I don't know of too many that did that kind of thing.
I was just wondering.
Did you see...
A lot of racism among white and black troops?
Not too much.
You know, you had some problems every now and then that would pop up, but they're the same kinds of problems that would happen back in the States.
You know, and it really wasn't caused from racism.
It was more of anything caused from tiredness or too many long hours or getting on each other's nerves.
It wasn't so much a racism type thing.
I think the media and movies have overplayed that aspect of it.
I really do.
Now, I may be wrong, but I feel like it's been overplayed.

Now, again, the latter part of the war, maybe it was more than, like I said, I was there in 68 and 69, so we were more interested in staying alive, taking care of each other than worrying about racism.
So the relationship between the blacks and the whites was good when I was there.
We always had a good relationship.
We didn't split off into little groups or things like that.
Was the relationship between the Americans and the Vietnamese the same way, or was it a lot different?
No, we didn't really have all that much contact.
The contact we had with civilians was usually pretty good.
We didn't really have any problems with them.
There wasn't a lot of racism between us and the Vietnamese.
Most of the Vietnamese we were around needed us.
needed the help, whatever.
So we didn't really, I don't recall any real racism against Vietnamese people, per se.
When you got home, how were you treated?
Were you treated a lot differently than you were before you left?
Well, not particularly as more, I think people wanted to just forget things.
There weren't any kind of celebrations or anything like that.
But other than that, I never experienced the negative things you see on TV either.
When I came home in 69, I never encountered anyone that showed me any disrespect.
There wasn't any brass bands, but there wasn't any riots or criticism or anyone calling me names or anything like that.
So I didn't experience any of those negative things at home.
I didn't realize that.
Do you think that it might have made a little difference being here in a conservative part of the country?
Probably so.
I think when you're in the conservative South, I don't know if people are more born to duty or whatever or loyalty to country or whatever, but I think coming from a conservative part of the country,

where nationalism is a big part of our life, played a part in that, as opposed to maybe growing up in California where it's a much more liberal society, more liberal values in some of these other places.

I think mostly probably if you went through the South and the Midwest, I think probably soldiers may have been viewed a little bit differently than they were, say, on the West Coast or possibly even the East Coast.
where people in the large cities, the big states, where maybe their values are a little bit more liberal than what we are in the conservative South.
Opinion, I don't know.
Who did you feel was responsible for losing the war?
Or what do you think made them lose the war?
Well, that's a hard one because I think we were prevented from doing some things that we needed to do to win the war.
I think that Congress, with the War Powers Act of 1973, kind of put an end to it.
We weren't able to fight the war to help the Vietnamese continue their Vietnamization program.
So I don't know.
There were just a lot of things that prevented us from fighting the war and winning it.
I think just mainly keeping us on the defensive
was the main thing that prevented us from winning the war.
I had skipped a question before, but how did you feel about ARVN when they used their help from the United States?
Do you think they were effective?
Yeah, they were some well-trained and very good, many were very good fighting men.
particularly the younger ones who were still somewhat idealistic and wanted to fight for the freedom of their country and things like that.
I think many of the Arvin soldiers that had been fighting this war for so many years, 20, 25 years or so, they were just more intent on survival.

But many of the younger Arvin soldiers, what little bit I know about them and being a little bit around them, were fighting the war and they felt like they were doing the right thing and they were motivated and there was a lot of patriotism for them in their country.
As far as I know, we worked pretty well together at times.
I never saw any real problem.
Did you see corruption in the structure of their military?
Really don't have any.
way of making that call, making that kind of judgment.
I really don't know.
Okay.
Let's see.
What do you think should have been done different about Vietnam?
I believe I asked you that already.
Well, I just think we should have went on the offensive and fought the war.
And I think if we would have done that with a
weapons and material, the things that we had, we would have come out ahead.
I don't know why we were prevented from that, from doing that, what our reasoning was, but you can't fight a war from a defensive position.
Do you think that they needed more troops there?
I think we had enough troops.
It was just a matter of using the firepower.
And I know you can read all the books and things about all the bombs that were dropped and the millions and millions of dollars and things like that.
But I think things might have been planned a little bit better.
Could have been planned a little bit better.
Of course, I'm not that knowledgeable about what officers and generals were thinking.
But I think most of the grunts felt like we could do a little bit better job than we did.
in being allowed to fight the war.
Do you have any idea of how that could have been done?
Or no?
Well, I think maybe if we'd have went on the offensive, went on in the north, would have played a big role.
Yeah, going and invading.
I think we might have, it would have cost a lot of lives, but if we'd have done it in the beginning of the early 60s, then again, it might have saved a lot of lives.
Who knows?
It's just an estimation, just a guess or whatever.

And had we maybe been allowed to go on into some of these other countries and into the Vietnam or to the VC camps where they were held up and not having to hide it from the media and things of that nature late in the war, like supposedly did happen, if I'd been on the up and up and went on and done these things as early as 63 or 64, we might have prevented a lot of things.
Only time will tell or won't tell.
It's just too late to make those kinds of guesses.
With the hindsight that you have, do you think we still should have gone to Vietnam?
Yes, I think we should have still did that.
I'm disappointed that we didn't finish it like we should have, but I think we were there in the beginning for the right reasons.
I think those reasons got blinded somewhere by other things, maybe financial or whatever, economy and things of that nature maybe.
Somewhere along in the beginning I think we were there for the right reasons and it got colored somehow.
So I take it from what you just said that you would still have volunteered?
I would have done it again.
I still think it was the right thing to do at that time for me, for me personally.
I would have still done it.
Okay.
Well, thank you very much.
I appreciate it.
You're welcome.
